title: surprising treatment of unspecified cflags
body:
I think spack's handling of default (unspecified) CFLAGS and CXXFLAGS
is surprising and incorrect.

Let's use xz utils (lzma compression) as a simple example.  xz is
straightforward autotools and has a tiny package.py script, using all
default AutotoolsPackage build machinery.

First, let's build xz manually (outside of spack), specifying only
--prefix and not CFLAGS.

$ ../xz-5.2.3/configure  --prefix=/home/krentel/work/install/
$ make

The generated Makefile has:

CFLAGS = -g -O2

And a typical compile line is (note the inclusion of -g -O2).

libtool: compile: gcc -std=gnu99 -DHAVE_CONFIG_H
-I. -I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma
-I../.. -I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/api
-I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/common
-I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/check
-I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/lz
-I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/rangecoder
-I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/lzma
-I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/delta
-I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/simple -I../../../xz-5.2.3/src/common
-DTUKLIB_SYMBOL_PREFIX=lzma_ -pthread -fvisibility=hidden -Wall
-Wextra -Wvla -Wformat=2 -Winit-self -Wmissing-include-dirs
-Wstrict-aliasing -Wfloat-equal -Wundef -Wshadow -Wpointer-arith
-Wbad-function-cast -Wwrite-strings -Wlogical-op -Waggregate-return
-Wstrict-prototypes -Wold-style-definition -Wmissing-prototypes
-Wmissing-declarations -Wmissing-noreturn -Wredundant-decls -g -O2 -MT
liblzma_la-common.lo -MD -MP -MF .deps/liblzma_la-common.Tpo -c
../../../xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/common/common.c -fPIC -DPIC -o
.libs/liblzma_la-common.o

So, I didn't specify CFLAGS and xz's configure script selected
CFLAGS='-g -O2' as its default.

But now, if we try spack install without specifying cflags, we get a
very different result.

$ spack  install  -v  --keep-stage  xz

Using --keep-stage, we go into the build directory and look at the
generated Makefile.

CFLAGS = 

And indeed, a compile line makes no mention of -g or -O2.

libtool: compile: /home/krentel/work/spack-repo/lib/spack/env/gcc/gcc
-std=gnu99 -DHAVE_CONFIG_H
-I. -I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma
-I../.. -I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/api
-I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/common
-I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/check
-I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/lz
-I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/rangecoder
-I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/lzma
-I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/delta
-I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/liblzma/simple
-I/home/krentel/work/spack-repo/var/spack/stage/xz-5.2.3-zaiqz5siodty64rxu4mqz4ayjogfbabw/xz-5.2.3/src/common
-DTUKLIB_SYMBOL_PREFIX=lzma_ -pthread -fvisibility=hidden -Wall
-Wextra -Wvla -Wformat=2 -Winit-self -Wmissing-include-dirs
-Wstrict-aliasing -Wfloat-equal -Wundef -Wshadow -Wpointer-arith
-Wbad-function-cast -Wwrite-strings -Wlogical-op -Waggregate-return
-Wstrict-prototypes -Wold-style-definition -Wmissing-prototypes
-Wmissing-declarations -Wmissing-noreturn -Wredundant-decls -MT
liblzma_la-common.lo -MD -MP -MF .deps/liblzma_la-common.Tpo -c
common/common.c -fPIC -DPIC -o .libs/liblzma_la-common.o

That is, the spack default is -O0 and no debugging symbols.

The problem is that spack is inserting an explicit CFLAGS='' (empty)
into the configure script.  Again, you can see this with --keep-stage
in config.log.  (Currently this is via the environment, not the
command line, but either way works the same.)

I think this is very surprising and actually incorrect.  Instead,
spack should recoginize that cflags is unspecified and pass along
'unspecified' by leaving off CFLAGS from the command line or the
environment.

If I put cflags='...' in the spec, then of course, spack should pass
that on to each package.  But if I omit cflags, then spack should omit
CFLAGS so that each package chooses its natural default.

I'm curious how spack users handle this.

Is everyone careful to always add cflags='-g -O2' to the spec?

Are people getting lots of unoptimized builds without debug symbols
and not knowing it?

Thanks,

--Mark
